body:
Any thoughts on this, @aiwalter and @TonyBagnall?

Also, @lmmentel and I had a discussion about this recently, in the context of `FeatureUnion`. @lmmentel also mentioned this in #1771. It came up in the metrics/distances as well, tagging @chrisholder, @eenticott-shell, and @Lovkush-A  for that.
My initial thought is that this is a good idea. Note, I do not have a good sense of 'long-term' consequences or 'second-order' effects of such a change.

> My initial thought is that this is a good idea. Note, I do not have a good sense of 'long-term' consequences or 'second-order' effects of such a change.

I guess the main negatives are:
* more methods in the extender contract (user contract stays the same). One could now argue whether the "more methods" in the extender contract make it easier to understand, or more complex to comply with. I'd be on the side that, in the balance of things, it makes it easire and more intuitive to extend, but I see why one could be of the opposite opinion.
* we're doing it differently from `sklearn`, effectively committing heresy. Extenders may be confused only because we are different from `sklearn` which has a very heavy footprint.

Not sure whether there are other negatives? Would encourage to shoot at the proposal.

to me, the primary reason for conforming to scikit design is so that our estimators can be used in their utilities such as cross validation. If this change means that is not possible, I am dead against it. And you may think it wont be a factor, but there are certain idiosyncrasies with scikit (Im no expert, but certain things dont work as I woul have expected, such as distances in knn), so I would like it tested thoroughly before inclusion. I am less concerned with the look of conformity, since as I understand it (limited capacity to think it htrough atm) most of the changes are internal and additional, so the user can ignore if they want.

> I am less concerned with the look of conformity, since as I understand it (limited capacity to think it htrough atm) most of the changes are internal and additional, so the user can ignore if they want.

Yes, that's also what I would expect towards `scikit-learn`. I.e., I wouldn't expect any interoperability issues, but we'd have to see.

issue.title: [ENH] Differencer NA handling - "fill zero" parameter

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
From a pair programming session with @lbventur (at the community meetup).

This PR solves #2478, it upgrades `Differencer` with NA handling parameter `na_handling`, which allows, besides the two current behaviours, a third behaviour `fill_zero` that fills zero.

This parameter replaces the boolean `drop_na` parameter, and adds deprecation with replacement at 0.13.0, and move to a `fill_zero` default.

Why is the `fill_zero` parameter a better default? It results in a "same index" and "no NA" condition at the end, which is the most compatible out of the alternatives when used in a pipeline. See also discussion (and user frustration) here: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2452 and here: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2451

issue.title: [ENH] design - init, parameter check, dynamic tags - conflicting interface requirements

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
We need to have a design decision on conflicting elements of our current interface specification.

These are:

1. `__init__` should contain no logic for input checking, and optimally no other logic. Such logic should be placed at the start of `_fit`
2. dynamic tags need to be set in the `__init__`, since tags are read at the start of the `fit` call which precedes the `_fit` call
3. we have the `fit_is_empty` tag, which can mean that `_fit` is never called for a given estimator, as well as estimators/object types that have no `fit` (such as distances)

Here, 1. conflucts with 2. and with 3., but 2. and 3. do not conflict with each other (I think).

I feel we need to think about potential ways to resolve this situation.

Related: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/1798
